passages.text: NVIDIA's guidance presents new upside to Hynix's HBM3eNVIDIA's new guidance presents three positive implications for SK Hynix's 12- HBM3e: 1) \(50\%\) memory content increase: Blackwell Ultra ramp- ups (using 288GB 12- hi HBM3e per GPU) just began this quarter following Blackwell (192GB); 2) no downturn concern: \(50\% +\) YoY growth in NVIDIA's data center revenue (mostly GPU) on track (not only JulQ but also OctQ, even without H2O China exports); and 3) low price cut pressure likely (for Hynix's 12- hi HBM3e): NVIDIA confirmed high gross margins ( \(70\% +\) ), even after using expensive HBM for two consecutive quarters (AprQ/ JulyQ). Since Samsung Electronics' 12- hi HBM3e shipments (to NVIDIA) are still minimal as of late August, Hynix's dominant market position appears stronger (vs a year ago 8- hi HBM3e). Samsung seems to be focusing on non- NVIDIA customers, such as AMD and Broadcom. Separately NVIDIA's updated comments on next- generation GPU Rubin (already in TSMC's fab, on annual cycle) should also suggest Hynix's mid- to long- term growth opportunities as the first mover of HBM4 (favorable 2026 contracts to be settled in Sept or at least sometime in 4Q ahead of competitors, in our view). Overall, we conclude NVIDIA's results (JulQ) and guidance (OctQ, Blackwell Ultra, Rubin) are good enough to expect Hynix's upbeat HBM sales/margin. Our Buy (Hynix) is based on record- high 2025- 26E OP and low multiples.

We visited one of LG CNS's data centers, located in Sangam, Seoul. What we learned: 1) full utilization with 24- hour working servers; 2) upbeat demand among manufacturing and financial companies exceeding current capacity (due to AI training/inferencing); and 3) well- established electric power supply and air cooling system (liquid cooling still in early stage). Management also noted long- term growth opportunities with US hyperscalers, who have committed to install lots of new AI servers/GPUs in LG CNS's operating data centers under DBO (Design, Build, Operate) model: land/buildings owned by private equity funds vs AI server/GPU by hyperscalers, and LG CNS operates data centers. LG CNS seems to be expecting \(50\% +\) growth of DBO revenue (our forecast: W500bn+ in 2025 vs - W300bn in 2024). LG CNS is currently participating in a few more data center construction projects to add 100MW+ (2025- 27) vs current 400MW (- 30% of Korea country's total ex telecom companies). Net- net, our tour takeaways clearly indicate strongly growing data center demand - too early to say AI bubble in Korea.

Our weekly channel check continuously indicates bullish sentiment for conventional server DRAM. Our new finding was strongly growing Sept order vs Jul- Aug. True, ASP hike is still \(5\%\) or less QoQ, but volume growth seems to be double digit \(0\%\) exceeding production. 4Q orders are also expected to be stronger than seasonal along with accelerating traditional server upgrade (to support AI ecosystem) in data centers. That said, we still see flatish PC DRAM spot price ex legacy DDR3/DDR4 (up again this week).
\(>>\) Employed by a non- US affiliate of BoFAS and is not registered/qualified as a research analyst under the FINRA rules.

Our PO of W100,000 is derived from 22x P/E based on 2025- 26 EPS. Given that CNS's IT services are based on multiple- year agreements (while price negotiations are mostly annual), we use two- year forward EPS. Local and global peers trade in the range of 10x 2025- 26 P/E to low- 20x. Korea's AI boom (e.g., the government's W100tn investment plan, etc.) could push the fair P/B close to the global sector average (low- 20x). Some local IT service providers (Lotte, POSCO, and Hyundai Auto affiliates) have already posted over 20x P/E.
Upside risks: stronger IT service orders particularly for cloud/AI, market- share gain, more effective cost cut, and innovative software development.
Downside risks: negative impact of US tariff and macro uncertainties (customers' capex cut), price competition with local peers, and unexpected cost increase (cloud sourcing, labor, R&D, etc.).

Our PO of W400,000 is derived from 2.4x 2025- 26E BPS. This is higher than the historical average (1.3x in 2014- 24) or 2017- 18 upturn level (1.9x) due to above- trend OP generation (50%+ above previous peak cycles) and market- dominant position (No. 1 market share in HBM). We note its closest US peer already trades at 2.0+ P/B despite lower margin profile vs Hynix.
Downside risks: bigger impact of US tariffs, HBM competition, and China's restrictions (rare earth, chip imports).

Upside risks: 1) upbeat HBM orders (from US Big Tech companies and various sovereign AI projects), 2) stronger commodity memory chip price hike, 3) Samsung Electronics' low yield using 1c node (DRAM) and \(200+\) layers (NAND), 4) stronger chip demand for smartphone/PC/server, and 5) more effective cost cuts (manufacturing, SG&A).
